THE BOAT RACE

Owner is Tadoussac the greatest river boat in Canada.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6.—The following are the particulars of the great steamboat race between San Francisco and Sacramento, which took place yesterday afternoon but for $2,000 a side and the championship of America between the two boats. The race was won by the steamer Tadoussac, which started from the wharf of the Grand Hotel at St. Louis. During the whole race the Tadoussac was ahead of the Sacramento, although she was considerably slower than her opponent. The race was won by the Tadoussac, which averaged about 14 miles an hour, while the Sacramento averaged only 12 miles an hour.

Sir John Macdonald is satisfied with the statement that there will be no general election for the Commons until May. Progressive candidates can therefore take it easy.

It would be interesting to the ratepayers to know whether or not the ratepayers have been approached to audit the civic accounts have been sent to the port to the Council, and it would be further interesting to know what such report is. We do not consider it right that these things should be kept hidden from the taxpayers. The public has a right to know what has been done with their money, and we trust that the required information will be speedily forthcoming.

It is reported that important changes are to be made during the present session of Parliament in the postal regulations. Drop letters will be charged at the rate of two cents each. The rate on letters for express mail will be three cents as for ordinary, except that the maximum weight allowance will be one ounce instead of half an ounce for a single rate. Registered letters will be charged ten cents instead of two cents.

The Government have made some important concessions to the North West members in the matter of second homesteads. We are not in possession of all the facts, but learn that second homesteads will be allowed to those settlers who would have been entitled thereto at the time the right to such privilege was abolished. Mr. Macdonald was largely instrumental in obtaining this concession from the Government.

To those who accuse Mr. Macdonald of all of being nothing but interested and being weak-kneed, we would say that such is not the case. We have every evidence that Mr. Macdonald is one of the hardest working members at Ottawa, and never allows an opportunity to pass by pressing the interests of his constituents into the hands of the Government. We consider the testimony of Mr. Macdonald, who opposed Mr. Macdonald's election, and who had since every opportunity of watching his actions as Ottawa is of influence, worth more than the opinions of a few politicians who mendaciously try to injure our member in the eyes of the public.

Commissioner Herchmer, in his annual report, deals at some length with the liquor question, and complains of the difficulties in enforcing the present law. He suggests that the manufacture and sale of beer be allowed in the provinces under very stringent regulations. We long since advocated the course suggested by the Commissioner, and still believe it is the proper course to be adopted. We hope that the Government will at once act on the advice of the Commissioner in this matter.

The Dakota half-breeds are raising a hue and cry because they are asked to pay taxes like white people. It does not appear to be any party in the States blaming the authorities for imposing such tax or sympathizing with the half breeds. It would be very different if the trouble arose in our North-West. The Government would then be attacked for tyranny over the oppressed.

GENERAL NEWS.

Rev. G. Blund fell in the Methodist church, in Kingston, dislocating his leg and breaking several ribs. He had just returned from amputation of his leg in New York.

There are divers rumors of a sudden and sensational ending of the proceedings of the Parson Case. It is said that Mr. Rossell will not advise the Parsonists to not offer any testimony, but to rest their case when Pigott and other geographic experts have been called. The case is now adjourned until next week.

During the last week of its stay in the United States, the Canadian Press was busy. His work will be chiefly examining bills sent from Congress. Twenty-two bills were examined and the majority of them were fair. The last day of Congress has not fairly begun.

Very cold weather was reported on the 21st of March, with snow falling in New England States. At Nashua, N.H., the mercury registered 36 below zero. In Montgomery, Tennessee, 26 below zero. Cold weather was also reported in Canada.

The Rev. Dr. Wild, of Toronto, in a sermon lately urged the Quebec Protestant to get an injunction against the Jesuit Estates Bill.

The question is whether the law of Canada has no power to incorporate the Jesuits, or does the law of Canada have the power to incorporate the Jesuits? He doubted whether, if a man were to shoot a Jesuit in the street, that the British law could punish him. It is the right of the British constitution for a Jesuit to exist in the Dominion. He said that the Jesuits would be able to get the Dominion parliament to pay the $400,000.

A mass meeting of Orangemen is to be held in Toronto on the 5th March for the purpose of petitioning the government to pass the Jesuit Estates Bill.

J. E. Campbell, of Hamilton, committed suicide by shooting himself. He was left about $25,000 a year ago, which he invested in the grocery business about a year ago, that is supposed to have ruined him.

The announcement that Prince Henry of Hesse-Homburg would probably marry Miss Lotzner, has been delayed owing to the discovery that the couple are already married. The lady is 28 years of age and the prince is 37.

A great head was taken on one of the tracklaying gangs on the Portage & Prince Edward Railway. On going to work he found that the gang had been working on the line without the consent of the company. He could not see how the incorporation of this body was legal. It would be expected that the company in the world. The British have no reason for a Jesuit to be on British soil. The preacher could not see how the Provincial government could fail to pass the bill, and yet not allow the incorporation of a legal order like the Jesuits. He said that the Jesuits were merely a party. A Jesuit pledged himself to the utmost of his power to uphold the Pope's pretensions of authority over all national kings, princes, and governments, all being subject with the Pope's sacred condemnation, and the Pope may be said to be supreme. The secular power is merely a privilege. The Jesuits are the only ones who can make a king. He who goes to death a Jesuit is declared a martyr, whereas he who goes to death a secularist is not only a hateful but a horrible thing.

THE TOWN ACCOUNTS.

Sir,—Those who have been before called upon to give an opinion as to whether the officers of public utility corporations are liable to receive praise, censure or advice, in such a degree as to make it proper for anyone to call for, at the hands of the citizens whom they have been chosen to serve. Let me examine and pass an opinion as to what was best done in the management of their taking off a great deal was promised in placing the affairs of the town in the hands of a few men. Two months have elapsed which should be sufficient time for them to make some progress. The mayor, in his executive capacity and as a member of the legislative body, has carried out the instructions of the council carried out. We all remember how, when the mayor came into office last fall, he objected strongly to the manner in which the accounts of the town had been kept ever since the last incorporation. He said it was only just to the ratepayers, and not contributing to the credit of the business men of the town, that he should be represented in the council. Others in the council shared these views, and the result admits of no question. The present mayor was one of the committee formed to examine the accounts and draft a scheme for having a satisfactory form of accounts established. Probably the fact that there was existing a matter of unsettled accounts during a certain period of time from being pushed through before the end of the year, but it should have been attended to then. We are convinced that the accounts are now in order, and placed in the present mayor's hands to be forwarded so as to come before the council with the most different system from the hitherto kept. Why was it that this was not brought forward to be presented upon the present council? If of course there was no excuse for keeping it back. I do not know if the accounts reported that the accounts were in order, but if they were kept, so if they recommended a change. I can hardly believe the fact, if the accounts were kept for that purpose, that the latter part of the year, that the rate payers would like to know also. It may be the charge immediately brought against them, that the accounts have been kept in the past, the past councils have been to blame, not the officials of the present council, but the instructions given them. In all matters that have engaged the attention of the council the same care has been taken to advantage in the keeping of the accounts. They have been doing and undoing, without any other apparent object than to placate the feelings of the ratepayers, whether they have been incorrectly reported, in that they have taken up the question of the salary of the town's handmaster a salary, and that equal to the combined salaries of two or three of the offices of the town, in order to take things easy. I think the town council are partly justified in doing a little economy and a great deal of advice, carefully administered.

Mr. H. H. Smith will be here on Sunday the 17th.

The snow has all gone and wagons are in general use.

The Meds are getting ready for their spring trip, and will start shortly and dispose of Mr. McLean, merchant of Fish Creek, was in town this week renewing old acquaintances.

Mr. McLean for purposes bearing Mr. Smith shortly to purchase goods. He was delighted with his last visit.

An English school is badly needed here, and if this council and our people will get a school up and build one, it will be a great blessing.

Two of our young men report seeing geese on Monday night, and William John had a very singular experience that day.

The new schoolhouse is progressing, and the children are enjoying its occupation. This is an important settlement and she old homes.

A meeting of the settlers will be held here on Wednesday, April the 17th, at 1 o'clock p.m., to form an agricultural society. It is to be hoped there will be a hearty attendance.

Mr. G. Carter, of Carlton, last spring bought seven turkeys from which he raised twenty-eight poults. He raised them for $25.00 each.

Mr. McLean, of Willoughby, brought in this week a large lot of eggs. He says raising turkeys costs one cent per egg.

It weighed thirty-eight pounds.

He made a present of it to an Irishman, someone thinking he was a Scotchman.

The event of the season took place at Batchelor on Monday last in the marriage of Mr. & Mrs. L. J. Miller. After the ceremony Elder Marion of Batchelor officiated. The ceremony was performed by the Reverend Mr. Miller. The groom is a highly respected citizen of this town, and the bride Miss De La Torre. The bride wore a black satin dress, rich trimmed with lace and plume. After the wedding breakfast, at 12 o'clock, the guests assembled at the residence until the following morning. The bride was the recipient of many valuable and useful presents.
